Communication



Characters do not have classes, instead skills are advanced by using the skill. For instance, fighting with an axe would raise your Axe skills, digging would raise your Mason skill, etc... Hiring a teacher or trainer can provide an increase the speed with which your skill levels advance.

Core Mechanic

The core mechanic of a skill effect is 50 + ({Skill} * {Ability}) - (penalty) = % chance of success. Penalties come from a range of places, though the most common is that it will be the target's {Skill} * {Ability}, as in Combat. In cases where there is no character target, the penalty will be set by the difficulty of the attempted action- the quality of a lock to be picked, for example, or the complexity of an item to be crafted. The penalty associated with an individual action are found under the description of that action in the skill's entry.

Bonuses

The vast majority of bonuses are applied as "virtual experience" to a skill (or ability)- experience which increases the character's skill (or ability) while used, but is lost when the item is put aside. An excellent tool will generally help an inexperienced character much more than a character with more refined technique.

Some rare items do provide bonuses directly to skills or abilities. These wonderous items generally require a more skilled character to get maximum effect from.

Magic Skills

Implementation of magic is way off, after a stable core system of skills and combat has been established and is comfortable. However, some discussion of the shape of that system would be appropriate on the topic Magic.

Skill Depreciation

Having an open skill system can cause many issues. One of these is that people can essentially become a "jack of all trades." by training each skill to its effective maximum then moving on to a new skill. This is unrealistic and game breaking. To correct this deficiency a system will calculate skill deprecation on unused skills. The essence is simply that skill that go unused for certain periods of time begin to slowly revert and your skill fades in ability.

  • If a skill is not used (checked through actions, trained, or listed as a hobby) for a number of play-hours equal to 100 / (the current rating), the character's Xp in that skill is reduced to the minimum necessarry to have the next lower rating. Thus a character with a 29 rating in a skill who has been logged in for almost 4 hours without using the skill, training the skill, or having it as a hobby has their Xp in the skill reduced to the minimum necessarry to have 28 ranks in the skill. The timer then resets to count down towards reducing the skill level again if it is not used.
  • The maximum experience earned towards a skills is recorded. Any events that provide experience towards improving that skill are tripled until that maximum rating is restored.
  • Disuse timers will only be active while a player is in-game so that if he or she does not sign on for a period of time their character is not adversely affected.
  • No skill's rating will ever revert below 1, once you have recieved any training in the skill you will always retain some basic understanding of that skill.

Such a system will force people to focus on the skill sets they both want and need to have. Training every single skill indefinitely to keep in practice would be possible but tedious.

Skill Depreciation Implementation

Specializations

Some skills have "specializations." A blacksmith may create any number of weapons, but they might excell at axes. When the skill is tested the character's specialization in that skill is added to their base value, giving them a higher effective value.

Specializations are subject to depriciation, though it happens at half the rate for the general skill. If a skill is listed as a hobby, the highest Specialization is protected from depriciation (though it recieves no bonus experience).

A player cannot generally view his character's ratings in Specializations.

Specialization Implementation

Locked vs Unlocked Skills and Specializations

Some Skills are "open," meaning any character is free to fail at that skill until they scrape together the experience to get to a first level of ability. Others are Locked. These skills cannot even be attempted, and will not appear on the character sheet, until the character has recieved at least 1 experience point worth of training from another. The clearest examples of "locked" skills are the skills for magic. Most of the Combat Styles are similarly locked (though two handed fighting is not).


Similarly, there are some specializations which are locked. While the skill may or may not be usable, without at least one rank in the appropriate Specialization certain actions cannot even be attempted. This is true of Spells,Designs, and most forms of tracking.
